column3: Should I consolidate all my pensions?
column4: Most of the time it makes sense to consolidate all your old workplace pensions as most of them will not have flexible access so you would not be able to put them into drawdown

column3: Are my fees to high and is my pension performing well?
column4: It does happen often that the fees on pension plans are very high. We will need to have a look at the pension and then be able to advise you on the fees and the performance of the funds.

column3: What are your qualifications?
Can I gather all my pensions and take the benefits when I am ready?
column4: Yes. Consolidating your various small pensions into one pension portfolio built around you and your needs, is a very sound strategy and is what we do for our clients. See our record of customer satisfaction on Vouchedfor.com

column3: I want to reduce my income tax bill legally and easily?
column4:
This is very straight forward to do by setting up your own personal pension plan, which reduces the amount of tax you will have to pay each year. Not only that, but the HMRC gives you an extra 20% free contribution for each payment that you make into your pension plan. 

I offer a fully online pension plan which will enable you to add to your pension plan, with nothing more than a normal debit card linked to your personal or business account. In 3 mins your additional payment will be arranged and automatically sent to your pension plan. It is that easy ! Modern 21st century technology at its best ! 

Just call me to see how easy it is.

column3: How do I save money into an ISA which will beat inflation for me ?
column4:
An "equity" ISA will over time beat all cash savings rates for you as an investor. You just need time to let the investment grow. Cash is only cash and has no growth potential at all. If you invest in an equity ISA you are investing in companies that actually make a profit and manufacture items. Companies you might have in your ISA portfolio can include: Amazon, Microsoft, BMW, Mercedes Benz, Tesla etc. Real companies that make and sell real stuff.

So e mail me and I will advise you accordingly. All on line for efficient service.

column3: When is the earliest that I can access my Pension.
column4: Currently, the earliest age at which you can normally draw your pension is 55. The government plans to raise this to age 57 from 2028 from whence it will then increase in line with any rise in the State Pension age. (The rise will not affect public sector schemes such as those covering firefighters, the police and the armed forces.)

column3: What tax do you pay on your pension?
column4:
When you take money from your pension pot, 25% is tax free. You pay Income Tax on the other 75%.

Your tax-free amount doesn’t use up any of your Personal Allowance – the amount of income you don’t have to pay tax on. The standard Personal Allowance is £12,500 for the 20/21 tax year.

The amount of tax you pay depends on your total income for the year and your tax rate.

column3: What is the minimum age applicable to Equity Release mortgages?
column4: 55 and over.

column3: I need help with my pensions
column4: You are not alone, its a complex subject which you need professional help with,to get the best from your money,please call me to see if I can help you.

column4: You are not alone, its a complex subject which you need professional help with,to get the best from your money,please call me to see if I can help you.

column3: I would like to release equity from my home/house.
column4:
Equity release is a great solution for some people but for others it pays to consider other options, avoid advertising and speak only to an Independent Financial Advisor, to discuss all of your requirements and gain the knowledge needed to make an informed decision. 
Colin Johnson

column3: I would like to look into insurance.
column4: Insurance or protection as we refer to it is a lot more complicated than most people think looking for information and professional help is the first step to getting it right. A free hours chat before going ahead is what I offer, so that your aware of the basic information before proceeding further.

column3: Can I take Income drawdown and how does it work?
column4: You are not alone, its a complex subject which you need professional help with,to get the best from your money,please call me to see if I can help you.

column3: How much do I need to retire.
column4: Everybody's situation is different but a rough guide is 20 times the income needed in retirement. e.g. income of £15,000 requires a £300,000 pension pot. ( £15,000 x 20 = £300,000 )

column3: How much should I be saving for retirement.
column4: Look at what you currently have in place and project what it will give you. Work out the shortfall and what amount is needed to achieve retirement goal. Rough rule is save 10% of your earnings.

column3: How do I get the best returns from my savings
column4: Regular reviews of your investments performance and charges are essentially the key.

column3: How do I simplify my old pension plans.
column4: Analysis through a qualified financial adviser will establish the best way to consolidate your existing pension plans.

column3: What is drawdown
column4: This is a pension product that lets you access your pension savings tax free cash and income whenever you need whilst reinvesting your remaining fund in a way specially designed to provide a retirement income.

column3: How do I save Inheritance Tax on my estate
column4: Make a will, Keep assets below IHT threshold, give assets away through Potentially exempt transfers, leave money to charity place assets in trust and Insure against the liability.

column3: What is a Stocks and Share’s ISA
column4: A stocks & shares ISA ,also known as an investment ISA ,is a tax-efficient investment account. A stocks & shares ISA allows you to invest in a wide range of shares, funds, investment trusts and bonds. This type of ISA offers greater growth potential than Cash ISA’s.

column3: Can you give me an idea of how much pension income I will have in retirement with my current pension provision.
column4: I often write reports for clients in this area so they know if they are on or off track for retiring in the manner and timescale they wish.

column3: I have a pension sharing order with a final salary scheme, can you help me implement it.
column4: Hi I have been dealing with pensions and divorce for over 10 years now and can easily implement a pension sharing order and help with pension planning going forward.

column3: When can I start drawing an income from my pension.
column4: At age 55 which is changing to age 57 from 2028

column3: How many years self employed accounts do I need to get a mortgage
column4: Most lender want to see at least two but some will work with one especially if you have a track record of employment in your current field.

column3: Whats the minimum deposit I need to put down on a buy to let mortgage
column4: Usually 25%

column3: What stamp duty do I pay if I buy a second property.
column4: If you do not sell your existing property you will pay the normal rate of stamp duty plus an extra 3% on the total purchase price, for properties above £40,000 purchase price.

column3: Can I keep my current mortgage if I move house.
column4: The vast majority of lenders will allow you to port your existing mortgage although you will have to prove affordability.

column3: Do you offer Limited Company Buy To Let Mortgages
column4: Yes I do

column3: Should I consolidate all my old paid up pensions with old employees and providers
column4: After careful analysis of the existing pensions, making sure there is no financial disadvantage to the client this is something we could look to do.

column3: What is the Residence Nil Rate Band?
column4: The Inheritance Tax residence nil-rate band (RNRB) is a transferable allowance for married couples and civil partners (per person) when their main residence is passed down to a direct descendent such as children or grandchildren after their death.

column3: Is Flexi Drawdown a good idea, compared to an annuity?
column4:
A key benefit of flexi-access drawdown is that your retirement savings stay invested even as you’re withdrawing cash from your pension pot. This leaves open the opportunity for investment growth, although it’s important to remember that your fund could go down as well as up in line with market performance.
Still, the alternative of buying an annuity, means you transfer your pension to an insurance company and forfeit the right to any capital and investment growth from your fund.
Although you receive a guaranteed annuity income for the rest of your life in exchange for your hard-earned pension, annuity rates are currently very low. Plus, you’ll miss out on the potential for any post-retirement growth in your pension investments.

column3: Do I have to purchase an Annuity?
column4: New rules introduced in April 2015 give you more freedom over what you can do with your pension pot. Deciding what to do can be tricky. We are here to simplify your decision and find the best option for you.

column3: What is inheritance tax?
column4:
Inheritance tax is a tax on the estate (the property, money and possessions) of someone who's passed away.
How much you pay depends on the value of your estate – which is valued based on your assets (cash in the bank, investments, property or business, vehicles, payouts from life insurance policies), minus any debts.
Importantly, there is normally no tax to pay if either:
•	The value of your estate is below £325,000.
•	You leave everything over £325,000 to your spouse, civil partner, a charity or a community amateur sports club.
If neither of the above applies, your estate will be taxed at 40% on anything above the £325,000 threshold when you die (or 36% if you leave at least 10% of the net value to a charity in your will).
However, this £325,000 tax-free threshold might be higher depending on your circumstances – in some cases as high as £500,000, or even £1 million. 

We'll explain more on this in our no obligation review service so please contact Anglian Wealth Management.

column3: Can you also arrange Buy to Let Mortgages
column4:
Yes we are regulated to provide Buy to Let Mortgages and residential mortgages for our clients.
We are whole of the market and can approach most lenders within that area of lenders.
There are different income criteria for Buy to Let mortgages and we will go through them with you when we advise you.

column3: I want to buy a hotel, can you arrange finance?
column4:
Yes we can arrange finance providing you have experience in this sector.
Again the criteria for each lender is different and as the number of lenders in this area of lending is small,  appetite in this area of finance is small. Speak to us and we can advise you of current state of play!

column3: What age do I need to be to qualify for equity release?
column4: The youngest borrower needs to be aged 55 or above.  However, in some cases, we can convert the property ownership into a sole name to make the case fit lending requirements.

column3: Who could benefit from equity release.
column4:
The list is endless.  

Equity release can be used to pay off an existing mortgage, especiialy one that is interest-only.  Equity release is not depenant on income so it is available to people over 55 who do not qualify for a standard mortgage.

Equity release can be used to raise capital to help out family, or home improvements.

Equity release can be used to settle divorce costs.

Equity release can provide a lump sum that can be used for any legal purpose.

Equity release can be used for home improvements.

column3: Give an example of equity release.
column4:
My neighbour is 87.  He and his wife live in a house that has not been modernised since the 1970s. In the summer, he is outside, cutting up old wooden pallets so he has firewood in the winter to light his coal fire.

He could raise a small amount, say £30,000 to have  a new kichen and bathroom fitted and have central heating fitted.

He could improve his remaining years by taking out equity release.

He would have no payments to make.

He could gift money to his grandchildren to help get them on the property ladder.

column3: Is equity release expensive?
column4:
Rates range from under 3% so they are very affordable.

Equity release mortgages can be serviced (so you pay the inerest each month and the loan does not increase) or the interest can be added.

We can discuss the best way forward for you.

column3: Can I move an equity release mortgage to a new proeprty?
column4: Yes, you can.  This is of course subject to meeting lender criteria.  Many people want to downsize as they get older and equiyty release mortgages are portable.

column3: Can you do equity release via the 'phone and internet.
column4: Yes.  However, in all cases we have carried out, we have always met the client face to face.  Our view is, if you are face to face, you can ensure the client fully understands what is being arrangeed for them and a face to face meeting can prompt questions that may otherwise be overlooked.

column3: What fees are involved?
column4: This all depends.  Sometimes  all costs can be covered by the equity release mortgaeg that is arranged.  So there can be nothing to pay up front.

column3: Is there a waiting time to start my equity release application.
column4: No.  We can generally arrange an apppinment for next day. Soetimes even the same day.

column3: Can you purchase a property with a 10% deposit
column4: It has been difficult to purchase a property in recent times with a 10% deposit, but there are now a few of main stream lenders that will lend on a 90% Loan to Value.

column3: How do you get the best interest rates
column4: We have access to the whole of market lenders and some lenders offer direct deals to brokers which are not available on the high street even if you went direct.

column3: What is stamp Duty
column4:
You usually pay Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT) on increasing portions of the property price when you buy residential property, for example a house or flat. SDLT only applies to properties over a certain value.
The amount you pay depends on:
When you bought the property.
How much you paid for it.
Rates from 8 July 2020 to 31 March 2021
You can also use this table to work out the SDLT for the purchase price of a lease (the ‘lease premium’).

Property or lease premium or transfer value	SDLT rate Up to £500,000	Zero
The next £425,000 (the portion from £500,001 to £925,000)	5%
The next £575,000 (the portion from £925,001 to £1.5 million)	10%
The remaining amount (the portion above £1.5 million)	12%

Rates from 1 April 2021 
You can also use this table to work out the SDLT for the purchase price of a lease (the ‘lease premium’).

Property or lease premium or transfer value	SDLT rate Up to £125,000	Zero
The next £125,000 (the portion from £125,001 to £250,000)	                        2%
The next £675,000 (the portion from £250,001 to £925,000)	                        5%
The next £575,000 (the portion from £925,001 to £1.5 million)	               10%
The remaining amount (the portion above £1.5 million)	                               12%

column3: Do I Qualify?
column4:
You need to be:

Over 55.
A UK homeowner.
Living in your home and it be worth more than £70,000

column3: Is it Safe?
column4: Equity Release  is fully regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) - all of our plans meet the Equity Release Council standards, offering additional protection.  Equity release is probably one of the most regulated financial products in the market and has many safeguards which have been in place for many years .  Reputable advisers, solicitors & lenders will belong to the Equity Release Council and adhere to their rules and guidance   which aim to ensure that its members are highly professional and act with integrity and transparency in offering high-quality products and services to customers.

column3: Do I need an adviser?
column4:
Yes
Equity release is an important financial decision. It’s a regulatory requirement set out by the FCA that you can only obtain an Equity Release plan after you have had the correct advice from a properly qualified adviser.If equity release isn’t right for you, we'll tell you.

column3: How long does it take?
column4:
Typically 6-8 weeks but this is very much dependent on an individuals specific  circumstances.
The process involves an initial  detailed fact find by the adviser to assess needs and suitability and answer any questions followed by a second meeting to make a recommendation (if appropriate) and answer any further questions .
If the you want to proceed then a valuation would be carried out by the lender who would then proceed to issue an offer and solicitors would finalise the conveyancing.

column3: Can I Move home?
column4: All our Lifetime mortgages plans allow you to move or port subject to lenders criteria and terms and conditions

column3: Can I take out Equity Release If I already have a mortgage in place?
column4: Yes, but this depends on how much you currently owe, how long you have left on your current mortgage and your current interest rate to see if it is a suitable alternative.

column3: Do I Qualify for Equity Release ?
column4: To qualify for equity release you must be over 55 years old and be a homeowner in the UK with a property worth a minimum of £70,000 .

column3: Can I do equity release if I still have a mortgage ?
column4: Yes. However, you will need to repay the mortgage using the money released. Any funds left over are for you to enjoy.

column3: Will I still own my own home ?
column4: Yes. With a lifetime mortgage you are in control and can live there as long as you want to. However, with a reversion plan the reversion company will own part or all of the property, although you can live there the rest of your life.

column3: Can I leave an inheritance for my family ?
column4: Yes. With some plans you can guarantee a percentage of your home's future value as an inheritance

column3: What happens when I die ?
column4: Your home will be sold once you and your partner have died. The sale proceeds will be used to repay the amount you owe and any money left will go to your estate.

column3: Will I ever fall into negative equity?
column4: With plans approved by the Equity Release Council, you will never owe more than the value of your home.

column3: Am I able to obtain a capital raising remortgage on my home to pay off unsecured debts?
column4: Yes this is something I should be able to help with however there are many things to take into consideration which I would cover as part of my advice process. For example, although consolidating unsecured debts into one affordable monthly mortgage repayment can make financial sense, it does mean that the whole borrowing would be secured on your home and so if you fail to make your mortgage repayments your home could be be repossessed. Also the term of the mortgage would generally be significantly longer than the remaining term on the unsecured debts and so you would end up paying more interest over the longer term.
